climbs.name: Wind Dance
climbs.fa: Glen Todd, Tony Lusk, Robin Lundeen

content.description: Climb over a few bulges and then follow the arete until you reach the anchors
content.location: After down climbing/rappelling the gully head down from the alcove and then left around the corner. Look for the sharp arete and spot the first bolt. If you start heading up the hill towards Thunderbirds you've gone too far.

content.description: Crux is getting over the low bulge. A little harder if you try to climb over the third bolt instead of working left.
content.location: Next to last climb on Upper Sky Valley.

climbs.name: Two Steps Forward One Step Back
climbs.fa: Tony Lusk, Joe Shiefman, Kent Brewner

content.description: Start out traversing along a slab then head generally right past a few bolts until you gain crack. At the top of the crack angle back left for a few moves and then clip the anchors.
content.protection: bolts, cold shuts at the top
content.location: Second route down the gulley. Shares the same starting area as Chain Lightning.

content.description: Some thoughtful slab climbing leads to amazing laybacking up steep face.  You'll know the crux when you get there.  Exit the layback using some interesting holds and push for the chains.        This is a great climb.
content.location: On the Left of the two cliffs go all the way down and around to the left.  "Thunderbolts" is the last bolted route you will see.

content.description: Consistent, good climbing on decent rock. Straight up past 6 bolts. Shares the initial bolt with Jimnastics. This route goes straight up past the first bolt, where Jimnastics heads left.
content.location: The uppermost route on the west side of lower Sky Valley.  Pretty easy to scramble down the west side to the base of the route.

content.description: Short face.  Longer more powerful moves than The Fire Inside to the right.
content.protection: Cold shuts.  Shares anchor with The Fire Inside.
content.location: Leftmost climb at the top of the hill, past Exposure in the Making.

content.description: Long right angling climb with a lot of laybacking in a shallow corner finishing on the face
content.location: On the west face of the lower sky Valley the first climb up the west gully from wind dancer

content.description: Start on an orange face, move right and into a seam, and then finish on a slabby face.  The movement in the seam is fantastic and there is plenty of friction for the feet.
content.location: The third route from the top of the gulley in the eastern section of Sky Valley.

content.description: Shares the first bolt with Thunderbirds, then heads left through steep terrain with mostly good holds. Eases up a bit and has a fun mantle to clip the chains. Good route.
content.location: 15 feet uphill from Dia De Los Muertos.  The start of this route and Thunderbirds is the uppermost bolts on the west side of Lower Sky Valley.

content.description: Start under a small roof in a shallow corner and climb up on good holds.  I though the crux was the devious slab climbing above the steeper climbing.  Another good warm-up before you head down and around the corner.
content.location: The second route past "Exposure in the Making".  The first one past is a 5.10 and significantly harder.  Make sure your on the correct route.

content.description:
Short face.  Thinner than Sky Diamond to the left with a tricky crux. 

  You can scramble to near the anchors on this and Sky Diamond to get climber photos that avoid the dreaded butt shot.
content.protection: Cold shuts.  Shares anchor with Sky Diamond.
content.location: Second climb from the left at the top of the hill, just past Exposure in the Making.

content.description: A newer climb to the crag to be sure, this lichen covered route offers varied 5.10 climbing on below average (for Mt Lemmon) rock. fairly sustained at 5.9-5.10 the entire climb, there is a low crux, pulling left from the corner onto the lower angled face, and a higher crux pulling a roof.
content.location: To the right of the crag's best climb, Thunderbolts.

content.description: A very airy 5.8- buttress that gives you amazing views of the San Pedro Valley on you way up.  Also a good warm up for the day.
content.location: On the left of the two cliffs this route is the third one down past two short 5.10s that sare an anchor at the top.

content.description: Striking orange face climbing.  Large holds and big moves down low lead to crux layback moves slightly above halfway.  Slabs out slighly at the top and keep your attention all the way to the chains.
content.location: On the Right of the two cliffs descend via the rappell gully.  Walk down the gully past three other sport climbs and around to the left.  The Orange face is very obvious.

content.description: A fun and interesting route with a little of everything; slab/bulge move down low (crux), some underclings, and then a vertical face to reach the anchors. Consider a spot off the deck as a demanding clip stance occurs ~10 feet into the climb.
content.protection: Bolts: well protected. Chains for rappel or lower off. Suggest a spot for the first clip.
content.location: Around the corner from the easier climbs at Sky Valley and immediately to the right of Hunger For The Time.

content.description: Devious start past the first three bolts on loose, grainy rock. A bit easier in the middle of the route, and another crux up high on better rock.
content.protection: 7 or 8 bolts. Bolted anchor with biners.
content.location: A few feet uphill from Serial Filler.

content.description: A unique crux move to the right side of the arete leads to cool moves on the narrow ridge above. Alternatively, one can face climb the back side of the arete rather than moving up the narrow ridge. Big blocks are solid.
content.location: furthest route to the right on Upper Sky Valley wall

climbs.name: Chain Lightning
climbs.fa: Tony Lusk, Joe Shiefman, Kent Brewner

content.description: Start off on slab and then climb a bulgy face.  This is a nice long route with pretty good rock.
content.location: The first route from the top of the gulley of the east section of Sky Valley.  (The east section is accessed by rapping or down climbing this gulley.  There are rap anchors behind a large bush at the top of the gulley.)

content.description: This climb is right of (Exposure In The Making) and can be toproped from the same anchors.

Sky Valley is one of the mid-mountain crags and is great for a warmer day area.  When there are waiting lines and everyone's dog hanging out at Ridgeline you can go here and get on some quality climbs without the feel of being at the gym.  This area consists of two crags and the climbing varies from slab to vertical to slightly overhanging.  Many climbs are shaded for most of the day as one crag is surrounded by large pines and the other's climbs are in a little grotto.All of the routes here are sport so all you need is a rope and a rack of draws and you are set.  Recommended climbs include: Exposure in the Making 5.8, Hunger for the Time 5.9+, Thunderbolts 5.11a, Driller on the Loose 5.11c/d, and Serial Driller 5.12b.
